I think his game is fun to play with friends and stand-alone.

Playing as a killer i find being very stressful and infuriating. You have to hit survivors two times to make them go into a dying state and hang them on a hook, they get 3 chances depending on how altruistic the other teammates are. Survivors can often be annoying or just really disrespectful towards you as a killer. That's why i don't really bother playing as a killer.

Playing as a survivor i find being less stressful because you are 4 players (often) against one killer. You have to repair 5 generators in order to power up the exit gates and flee, and you will always be able to help in any way in any situation you are in. In a chase you can make a distraction, while the teammates can finish the generators. While not in  a chase you can repair generators, sabotage hooks, heal others, yourself and finally take hits for others after opening the exit gates to flee.

It's fun, but will get repeatable after quite some time.

Campers and Tunnelers however... (killers that "try-hard") burn them. Burn them all. (ironic isn't it? since i said disrespectful survivors is a thing in this game... heh!)
Estou tendo muita dificuldade, pois toda vez que saio do gancho o controle inverte. Gostaria que solucionassem.

The game had perfect ultrawide (21:9) support with a small line added to the config file before the February update came out. The reason people buy ultrawide monitors is to get a more immersive experience but the way the game treats anyone but a 16:9 monitor user since the update is that it limits how much of the game world they can see. For ultrawide users, it means that their horizontal FOV is exactly the same as that of 16:9 users but vertically the image is severely cropped, so that you can't even see the legs of your character or anything behind it. The developers' argument for the handicapping is that a higher FOV gives an unfair advantage, yet even the most competitive first-person shooters like CS:GO support ultrawide by showing more of the game world.

Where to begin...

I've written something like 2-3 reviews for this game over the years, and deleted them as I changed my mind, or went back to the game like an abusive relationship, but I think this review here will be final.

Pros:

1.  It's horror-themed, and arguably the most influential and popular asymmetrical PVP game out there.

2.  It has some good licensed content, which is rare.

3.  The basic gameplay loop has a lot of fun to it at first, and there's opportunities for both sides to be rewarding, in certain situations.

4.  Tons of cosmetic content, challenges for extra BPs, tons of events, tons of weird sexual fanart in the Community tab if you've missed your calling in life, etc.

Cons:

1.  The first and most prominent con here is that the gameplay loop has gotten stale over the years, and without the focus on alternative objectives/modes to keep it fresh, the devs have elected to just inject a lot of content every month into the game to keep it vibrant.  And after all these years, it's just not doing it for me anymore.  I was the last person in my group to give up, and I'm a bit stubborn in that way.  I don't mind pushing with difficult competitive games if there's a payoff ahead for me, but DBD doesn't have that payoff and it's just gotten worse for me as a player.

DBD needs varied gameplay modes or objectives, because gen rush has dominated for so long it's held sway over every single update, every single complaint on either side, and every single balance patch.  The game has been around for so long you have a huge disparity between really good long time players and newer players finding their balance, and the meta has caused balance changes to make it much harder on newer survivors especially.

The point here is that the devs need to reinvent the game and expand its playability, instead of making new killers and survivors and then having to spend the interlude between content desperately trying to make it all shoe-horn into the stupid gen rush meta.

2.  Killers.  Playing as kilers in DBD is, all other things equal, a power position.  Except that most of the killer players on Steam disagree, and the gameplay balance caters to their complaints rather than addresses them.

I'll explain:

I spend a fair bit of time over the years while waiting for queues reading steam forum discussions, because it's easy, free, often cheap entertainment.  And the general idea for most killer mains is that survivors are overpowered and they're being bullied, etc.  Except this view doesn't do the reality any justice.  

See, people who play killer all day, and over and over again, climb the pathetic excuse for MMR's ranks, and eventually reach a tier where they encounter Sweatlord-tier survivors, which are invariably Survivor With Friend professionals, all using meta builds and voice comms.  And when most killers reach this level, suddenly the wins stop being normal and start being rare.  They hit that skill plateau, and it becomes unfun for them, because they're getting run around by the rare 1-3% of people in the game who have achieved red/iridescent rank 1 and play this competitively all the time.  

So what do they do?  They go to the forums and whine, they go to the devs and whine.  They play the victim card, because that's rewarding and doesn't require the supposed victim face any scrutiny at that point, and claim the game is survivor-sided, because they hit a point where it is harder for them and they've plateau'd hard.  Are they justified in this?

No, for two main reasons.  One, the survivors regularly giving them fits are, per Steam achievements alone, single digit  percentages of total players of the game.  This makes them a verified minority, and thus they cannot be the only experiences the killer is having.  So it stands to reason that this is an issue of MMR/player skill rather than overall gameplay balance.  After all, I've solo queued for several years (again being the last of my player group to give up on this mess), and most of my rando queue allies are potatoes at best.  Especially with the influx of free EGS players and free console players over the last year or so.  Two, the killer is still the power position here. 

Let's look at what DBD Killers have going for them:  Uh, they can't be killed or meaningfully hurt in any way.  They have utmost access to the map, and faster speeds.  They have powerful aura reading perks to help killers who got bored of hunting fish in a barrel.  

So what's this about killers being bullied?  Let's go over the examples - 
1.  Survivor crouched several times in rapid succession, causing heavy mental trauma.
2.  Survivor used a flashlight to blind me, which is a valid in-game tactic (just like my own hook camping lol).
3.  Survivor used a key/chance to find a hatch and escape my wrath, denying me my just 4k.
4.  Survivor said mean things in the post-game chat, and I had to look and I had to be offended because I have no willpower or impulse control.
5.  Survivor used mechanics meant to counter killer toxic behavior like DS and DH and that denied me victory for 10 more seconds, so I'm calling BS.

Etc. etc.  Meanwhile, I've pulled out various killers over the years, no perks, no levels invested, and 4kd newbie groups so pathetically easy  it was sad.  Why?  Because it's about hunting and thinking like a survivor.  I don't need aura reading perks when I know where I would hide in a given situation, or how to make survivors three-gen themselves for easy pickings, or how to use a man as bait so his friends come for him.  I don't need crutch perks to win against average randos thrown together without any sense of unity or meta.  So if the game was survivor-sided, why am I dominating with nothing at low to mid level killer play?  

It's almost like the issue isn't balance at those levels.  Almost like... the game needs to separate tryhards into their own tryhard league, so they can try to out-toxic each other while everyone else just tries to have fun.  But yeah, killers are bullied and they have it rough.  It's like listening to Cartman sometimes.

3.  I don't know at this point.  So much of the issues I've had with this game is about how balance changes are dominated by people in a position of power in a match struggling with a minority, so everyone else needs to be nerfed as a result.  But you don't see situations where these killers recognize weaklings and play sportingly.  No, they sandblast them like soup crackers with all their crutch meta perks and anti-loop killers with the justification that red ranks hurt them, so therefore all survivors must be tarred with the same brush.  Like, okay.  How are you complaining that you're being bullied when you're so eager to abuse people clearly at your own whim?  Is moral myopia a power difficult to attain, or can I get it if I get promoted at work enough?  How does that work?

Which really comes down to the point of this review.  The gameplay is so stale and so bound up in its own self-defeating meta that the community that's been here for years has grown toxic on both sides.  The game doesn't punish bad behavior which causes this toxicity in many cases, which is why the developer's name is pretty ironic.  And with that loveletter, I'm done with this game.

Really fun game, developers constantly adding new content/in game events. Very grindy, but it has gotten better since 2016 w/ more blood point opportunities. Most of the really good perks are from free characters + there is the shrine to have opportunity to unlock perks you don't have. Best w/ friends as a survivor but tons of hours to sink in as killer as well.
